raw_text:
'Strong dollar' call halts slide
 
 The US dollar's slide against the euro and yen has halted after US Treasury Secretary John Snow said a strong dollar was "in America's interest".
 
 But analysts said any gains are likely to be short-lived as problems with the US economy were still significant. They also pointed out that positive comments apart, President George W Bush's administration had done little to stop the dollar's slide. A weak dollar helps boost exports and narrow the current account deficit. The dollar was trading at $1.2944 against the euro at 2100GMT, still close to the $1.3006 record level set on 10 November. Against the Japanese yen, it was trading at 105.28 yen, after hitting a seven-month low of 105.17 earlier in the day.
 
 Policy makers in Europe have called the dollar's slide "brutal" and have blamed the strength of the euro for dampening economic growth. However, it is unclear whether ministers would issue a declaration aimed at curbing the euro's rise at a monthly meeting of Eurozone ministers late on Monday. Higher growth in Europe is regarded by US officials as a way the huge US current account deficit - that has been weighing on the dollar - could be reduced. Mr Snow who is currently in Dublin at the start of a four-nation EU visit, has applauded Ireland's introduction of lower taxes and deregulation which have helped boost growth. "The eurozone is growing below its potential. When a major part of the global economy is below potential there are negative consequences... for the citizens of those economies... and for their trading partners," he said. Mr Snow's comments may have helped shore up the dollar on Monday, but he was careful to qualify his statement.
 
 "Our basic policy, of course, is to let open, competitive markets set the values," he explained. "Markets are driven by fundamentals and towards fundamentals." US officials have also said that other economies need to grow, so the US is not the main global growth engine. Economists say that the fundamentals, or key indicators, of the US economy are looking far from rosy. Domestic consumer demand is cooling, and heavy spending by President Bush has pushed the budget deficit to a record $427bn (£230bn). The current account deficit, meanwhile, hit a record $166bn in the second quarter of 2004. For many analysts, a weaker dollar is here to stay. "No end is in sight," said Carsten Fritsch, a strategist at Commerzbank . "It is only a matter of time until the euro reaches $1.30." Some analysts maintain the US is secretly happy with a lower dollar which helps makes its exports cheaper in Europe, thus boosting its economy.
llama3.2:1b: The US dollar's slide against the euro and yen has halted after US Treasury Secretary John Snow said a strong dollar was "in America's interest". However, analysts believe any gains are short-lived due to significant problems with the US economy. The dollar continues to trade at record levels but is expected to decline in the coming months. The European Union has called the dollar's slide "brutal" and blamed it on the strength of the euro for dampening economic growth. US officials have argued that other economies need to grow, so the US cannot be the main global growth engine. Economists say the fundamentals of the US economy are looking far from rosy.
llama3.2:3b: US Treasury Secretary John Snow says strong dollar is in America's interest, halting slide against euro and yen. Analysts say gains are short-lived due to significant economic problems in the US. Policy makers in Europe blame euro's strength for dampening growth; a weaker dollar boosts exports and reduces current account deficit. Mr Snow praises Ireland's growth but warns of negative consequences if global economy underperforms.
gemma2:2b: The US dollar has halted its slide against the euro and yen after Treasury Secretary Snow stated a strong dollar was beneficial for America.  However, analysts remain skeptical, pointing to persistent economic challenges in the US, including a weak consumer market, high budget deficit, and record current account deficit. Despite Mr. Snow's comments supporting a strong dollar, some believe a weaker dollar is likely to persist due to fundamental economic issues in the US.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The US dollar has declined against both the euro and yen due to concerns over the economic situation in the European Union. Analysts are optimistic about positive comments from President Bush but warn that little can be done to prevent the dollar's slide further. Some EU policymakers have called for measures to counter the strong dollar, while others believe it is too late to reverse its impact. The US economy remains weaker than expected due to factors such as a growing deficit and rising unemployment. A stronger dollar could help boost exports and narrow the current account surplus, but it still faces challenges in the market. Some economists predict that a lower dollar will continue to be beneficial for American companies and businesses operating in Europe.
qwen2.5:1.5b: US Treasury Secretary John Snow's statement on a strong dollar halting the slide, despite concerns about persistent problems and lack of action from Bush administration to stop the decline. This was overshadowed by ongoing eurozone economic growth issues. Analysts predict short-lived gains due to continued US dollar weakness affecting exports and current account deficit.
qwen2.5:3b: US Treasury Secretary John Snow's statement that a strong dollar was in America's interest halted the US dollar's slide against the euro and yen. However, analysts remain cautious about any gains, pointing to significant problems within the US economy such as a weakening domestic consumer demand and rising budget deficit. Analysts also noted the dollar remains below its November 10 record level due to factors like weak growth in Europe. While policy makers in Europe criticized the dollar's slide, Snow's comments praised Ireland's economic reforms but stressed that open markets should determine exchange rates. Despite this support for a strong dollar, analysts believe the current account deficit may persist, with many seeing a weaker dollar as more sustainable given its benefits to US exports.
opencoder:1.5b: The US dollar's slide against the euro and yen has halted after US Treasury Secretary John Snow said a strong dollar was "in America’s interest". But analysts pointed out that positive comments apart, President George W Bush’s administration had done little to stop the dollar’s slide. The dollar was trading at $1.29. Against the euro at 2,100GMT, it was still close to the $1.3006 record level set on 10 November. In Europe, policy makers called the dollar's slide "brutal" and have argued that the strength of the euro could dampen economic growth.
smollm:1.7b: The strong dollar has halted after US Treasury Secretary John Snow said a strong dollar was "in America's interest". Analysts pointed out that positive comments apart, any gains are likely to be short-lived as problems with the US economy were still significant. They also pointed out that positive comments apart, President George W Bush's administration had done little to stop the dollar's slide. A weak dollar helps boost exports and narrow the current account deficit. The dollar was trading at $1.2944 against the euro at 2100GMT, still close to the $1.3006 record level set on 10 November. Against the yen, it was trading at 105.28 yen, after hitting a7-month low of 105.17 earlier in the day.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about the US dollar's strength against the euro and yen. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence says that the US dollar has halted its slide against the euro and yen after John Snow, the Treasury Secretary, mentioned the strong dollar is in America's interest. That's a key point. But then analysts note that while there were some gains, they might not be long-term because the US economy still faces issues.

Next, it talks about the economic situation, noting problems but not much stopping the slide yet. President George W Bush's administration didn't do much to stop it either. So, both the strong dollar and the US government's economic policies aren't enough.

The part about the dollar being weaker against the yen is interesting too. Against the euro, the dollar was at 1.2944, just below its previous record of 1.3006. Against the yen, it's at 105.28, which is higher than the seven-month low of 105.17. So, stronger against the euro and weaker against the yen.

Policy makers in Europe are calling the dollar "brutal" because the euro's strength has damped economic growth there. But it's unclear if European ministers will declare something to stop the euro rising next week. Higher growth by other EU countries could help reduce the US deficit.

 snow, who is on a visit, praised Ireland's measures like lower taxes and deregulation, which helped boost growth. His comments might have partly stopped the dollar, but he said things are still uncertain.

Economists agree that the US economy's fundamentals (like consumer demand) are down, and spending by Bush is pushing the deficit to record levels. The current account deficit hasn't closed yet. Analysts think a weaker dollar could continue forever, with some saying the US is secretly benefiting from it.

Putting this all together, the main points are: the dollar is still in a slide but analyst expectations say it might end soon; both stronger against euro and weaker against yen; European concern about economic growth being damped; policy measures by governments; and economists' views on continued weakness of the dollar.
</think>

The US dollar's strength against the euro and yen has halted its decline, with analysts cautioning that any gains may be short-lived. The dollar is still trading just below its 2013 record levels against the euro but near one. Against the yen, it's slightly stronger. Policy makers in Europe are warning of a brutal move due to the euro's strength, while doubts remain about whether ministers will declare action. Higher growth elsewhere could help reduce the US deficit. Snow praised Ireland's reforms and saw gains, though he emphasized economic uncertainty. Analysts expect the dollar to continue its weakness, with concerns it may persist forever.
tinyllama:1.1b: The US dollar has halted a slide against the euro and yen after US Treasury Secretary John Snow noted that "in America's interest", and said positive comments from President George W Bush had not stopped the dollar's decline. Despite a weak dollar, policy-makers in Europe are yet to declare a declaration aimed at reducing the euro's rise at a meeting of Eurozone ministers later in the week. The US economy is seen as being below potential, with negative consequences for citizens and trading partners. Despite the dollar's strength, some analysts believe it will remain high for "time until the euro reaches $1.30".
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, the US dollar's decline against the euro and yen has been halted following comments by Treasury Secretary John Snow, who argued that a strong dollar is beneficial to the US economy. However, analysts have warned that any gains are likely to be short-lived due to the ongoing global economic challenges and President George W. Bush's administration's limited impact on the dollar's value. In response, officials in Europe have called the dollar's decline "brutal," while politicians in the US aim to decrease the country's current account deficit.
phi:2.7b: The US Treasury Secretary said that a strong dollar was "in America's interest," but this did not stop the US dollar from continuing to slide against the euro and yen. Policy makers are considering measures to curb the euro's rise, but higher growth in Europe could reduce the large current account deficit of the US. Analysts believe that the fundamentals of the US economy are weak, with consumer demand cooling and a record budget deficit. A weaker dollar may be here to stay.
orca-mini:3b: The US Treasury Secretary said a strong dollar was in America's interest, but analysts warned that gains would be short-lived as problems with the US economy remained significant. The euro's rise has been blamed for dampening economic growth and the current account deficit, but higher growth in Europe is seen as reducing the huge US deficit.
hermes3:3b: US dollar slide halted after Treasury Secretary John Snow says strong dollar is beneficial. Gains likely short-lived due to US economic issues. Dollar trading at $1.2944 against euro and 105.28 yen against yen.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The US dollar's slide against the euro and yen has halted after US Treasury Secretary John Snow said a strong dollar was "in America's interest". Analysts say any gains will be short-lived as problems with the US economy persist. The eurozone is growing below its potential, which could have negative consequences for those economies and their trading partners. Although Mr. Snow qualifies that markets are driven by fundamentals, some analysts believe a weaker dollar is here to stay, as it helps make exports cheaper in Europe, boosting the economy.
chatgpt-4o-latest: The US dollar's decline against the euro and yen paused after US Treasury Secretary John Snow reaffirmed support for a strong dollar, though analysts expect the gains to be short-lived due to ongoing economic issues. Despite Snow's comments, the Bush administration has taken little action to halt the dollar's slide, which benefits US exports and helps reduce the current account deficit. European policymakers have expressed concern over the euro's strength, which they blame for slowing economic growth, but it is unclear if they will take action. Snow, visiting Europe, emphasized the need for higher European growth to help address the US deficit. While he defended market-driven exchange rates, US officials argue that global growth should not rely solely on the US. Economic indicators suggest continued weakness, with slowing consumer demand and record budget and current account deficits. Analysts predict the dollar will remain weak, with some suggesting the US quietly favors a lower dollar to boost exports.
stablelm2:1.6b: US Treasury Secretary John Snow's statement that a strong dollar is in America's interest has halted the decline of the US dollar against the euro and yen, but analysts argue any short-term gain will likely be temporary due to significant issues with the US economy. A weaker dollar benefits exports and reduces current account deficits. The dollar was recently trading at $1.4 compared to its previous record high in November. Despite European officials' criticism of the slide as "brutal," it is unclear whether Eurozone ministers will issue a declaration aimed at curbing the euro's rise during their monthly meeting later this week. While some US officials have praised Ireland's tax and deregulation reforms, which helped boost growth, fundamentals or key indicators for the US economy are looking poor compared to other economies.
granite3.1-dense:2b: US Treasury Secretary John Snow's statement that a strong dollar is "in America's interest" temporarily halted the euro and yen's slide against the US dollar. However, analysts predict any gains will be short-lived due to lingering economic issues in the US. These include a large current account deficit ($166bn in Q2 2004) and a budget deficit (now $427bn). Higher growth in Europe is seen as a potential solution to reduce the US's persistent trade imbalance, but this doesn't seem likely given the EU's own economic challenges. The euro's strength has been blamed for deterring economic growth in some European countries. Experts predict the dollar will continue its downward trend, with many believing it may reach parity with the euro ($1.30). Some even speculate that a lower dollar benefits US exports in Europe.
reference: The US dollar's slide against the euro and yen has halted after US Treasury Secretary John Snow said a strong dollar was "in America's interest".Higher growth in Europe is regarded by US officials as a way the huge US current account deficit - that has been weighing on the dollar - could be reduced.US officials have also said that other economies need to grow, so the US is not the main global growth engine.The dollar was trading at $1.2944 against the euro at 2100GMT, still close to the $1.3006 record level set on 10 November.Some analysts maintain the US is secretly happy with a lower dollar which helps makes its exports cheaper in Europe, thus boosting its economy.But analysts said any gains are likely to be short-lived as problems with the US economy were still significant.A weak dollar helps boost exports and narrow the current account deficit.When a major part of the global economy is below potential there are negative consequences... for the citizens of those economies... and for their trading partners," he said.Economists say that the fundamentals, or key indicators, of the US economy are looking far from rosy.Mr Snow's comments may have helped shore up the dollar on Monday, but he was careful to qualify his statement.
